meanings.definition: To calm or soothe someone's anger or anxiety.
meanings.sent1: She tried to mollify her upset friend by offering a hug.
meanings.sent2: The teacher's kind words helped mollify the student's fears about the test.
meanings.sent3: The puppy's playful antics never failed to mollify the grumpy old man.
meanings.sent4: Music has a magical ability to mollify even the most troubled souls.
meanings.sent5: The soothing sound of rain helped to mollify her anxious mind.

meanings.definition: To make something less severe or intense.
meanings.sent1: Adding cream to the coffee helped to mollify its bitter taste.
meanings.sent2: The apology did little to mollify the anger of the offended party.
meanings.sent3: The colorful decorations mollified the stark appearance of the room.
meanings.sent4: Time has a way of mollifying even the harshest memories.
meanings.sent5: A smile can sometimes mollify a tense situation more effectively than words.
